block.p: MARKETS

The S.E.C. took the first big step toward round-the-clock trading on the New York Stock Exchange, approving a request to extend Big Board hours beyond 4 P.M. The extension of trading to 5 P.M. for individual stocks and 5:15 for "baskets" of securities is the first phase in the exchange's plan to offer 24-hour trading. [ Page A1. ]
Stock trading dropped to its slowest pace of the year. The Dow industrials edged ahead 5.59 points, to 2,892.22. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed. [ D14. ]
MARKETS

The S.E.C. took the first big step toward round-the-clock trading on the New York Stock Exchange, approving a request to extend Big Board hours beyond 4 P.M. The extension of trading to 5 P.M. for individual stocks and 5:15 for "baskets" of securities is the first phase in the exchange's plan to offer 24-hour trading. [ Page A1. ]
Stock trading dropped to its slowest pace of the year. The Dow industrials edged ahead 5.59 points, to 2,892.22. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed. [ D14. ]
The dollar was lower on continued turmoil following a valuation adjustment to the Swedish krona. Gold prices were mixed. [ D15. ] Prices of cotton futures soared to a 10-year high. [ D15. ] COMPANIES
LTV is putting its aircraft and military electronics operations on the block to help meet future pension obligations. [ D1. ]

Microsoft has quietly begun recruiting talented scientists for its first basic research center. [ D1. ] Apple Computer confirmed that it would cut its work force by 10 percent, or about 1,560 people. [ D14. ]
Southern California Edison and Los Angeles's municipal utility said they would cut their emissions of carbon dioxide by 20 percent in the next 20 years. [ D1. ]
Federated named Michael Gould to succeed Marvin Traub as chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, and both men painted a rosy picture of the retailer's future. [ D1. ]
K Mart earnings rose 7.3 percent in the first quarter. Profits fell nearly a third at Toys "R" Us. [ D4. ]
Domestic airlines cut summer ticket prices by as much as 20 percent, following the lead of Northwest Airlines. [ D4. ]
Orion announced a restructuring to reduce interest payments by about $400 million. [ D5. ] A Time Warner subsidary will focus on using the radio spectrum in mobile communications. [ D17. ]
National City offered to acquire Ameritrust in a stock deal worth about $860 million. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL

Soviet approval of a free-emigration law removes a major obstacle to U.S. trade concessions and credits. [ A1. ] Soviet economists began meeting with American professors to draw up a plan that they hope could save the Russian economy. [ A7. ]
A Soviet spacecraft may be carrying Britain's first astronaut, but it is without the millions of dollars worth of Western ads that were originally planned for the mission. [ D17. ]
Vice President Quayle pressed Japanese officials to open Japan up to more American exports and investments. [ D2. ]
The Indianapolis 500 on Sunday will once again be a showcase of British automotive design and engineering skills. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY
A handful of banks are taking advantage of a financing technique that allows them to borrow funds in a way that does not require payment for deposit insurance. [ D6. ]
The Supreme Court refused to adopt a uniform Federal rule governing "derivative lawsuits" by shareholders. [ D6. ]
A new study concludes that hiring older workers makes good economic sense for businesses. [ A16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS

The proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico is renewing an old debate: Should a German or Japanese company with a Mexican factory gain the same access to the U.S. as companies owned by Mexicans or Americans? Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [ D2. ]
Salick Health Care has developed its own niche within the health care industry, analysts say. Market Place. [ D8. ]
A campaign for Embassy Suites will turn Garfield into the Cheshire cat, fading in importance. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D17. ]
